framedata.cancel: N SP J IC R SB

properties: Minagi extends out her hand in a short punch.

framedata.cancel: N SP J IC f5B SB

properties: Minagi offers the opponent a ticket that for some reason causes pain.
Minagi swings her bag in front of her. Has a very powerful hitbox. Most useful in neutral. Can combo into many of her specials and supers when Michiru is properly set up.
Minagi does one downward swipe into an upward swipe with a spread of paper tickets. Second hit launches.

variations.notes: Minagi does one downward swipe into an upward swipe with a spread of paper tickets. Second hit launches.
Minagi does one downward swipe into an upward swipe with a spread of paper tickets. Second hit launches.

framedata.cancel: N SP J IC R SB

properties: Minagi thrusts a ticket forward while crouching. Unfortunately not a low.

framedata.cancel: N SP J IC f5B SB

properties: Minagi does an apologetic bow. Hits low, but has less range than 2A. Very fast startup and crucial to her high/low game.
Minagi extends her legs out to trip the opponent. Good for getting simple knockdowns midscreen into Michiru shenanigans. For combos you'll be using 5C more often.

framedata.cancel: N SP J AD IC R

properties: Minagi swipes under herself with a ticket. Exceptionally fast.
Minagi kicks at an angle towards the ground.
Minagi does a flip kick which hits mostly in front of her. Used in her corner juggle loops and can be useful when challenging air-to-air. Causes downward momentum on aerial hit.
Similar to 5A except the hitbox is slightly smaller and it has forward momentum. Used in Minagi's 66AxN corner carries and in pressure.
Identical to f5B with forward momentum. Strong neutral tool for hassling the opponent.
Minagi dashes forward and swipes down with a ticket. Minagi's only grounded overhead, and also her only ground normal that can't be cancelled with S commands.
Similar to 2A except the hitbox is slightly smaller and has forward momentum.
Similar to 2C with different placing of the hitbox and forward momentum. Good for catching people blocking high at a distance.
Minagi does an upward swipe from dashing, identical to the second hit of 5C. This is Minagi's main way of launching opponents.
Can be IC canceled to start a combo.

variations.notes: Can be IC canceled to start a combo.
Can be IC canceled to start a combo.
Can be IC canceled to start a combo.

properties: Regular air throw. Opponent lands directly below Minagi.

5S - Chiruchiru Setup (ちるちる構えて) Michiru enters her "ready" stance. In this stance, she cannot move but her assist specials are much faster and some get unique properties. When Michiru completes a readied attack, she will return to her normal stance. Cancelling into this move and its variants is crucial to Minagi's gameplan. 5S - Chiruchiru Stop Setup (ちるちる構え止め) Michiru leaves the "ready" state and can move again.

6S - Chiruchiru Right (ちるちる右よ) Orders Michiru to move right. Cannot be used while Michiru is readied. 4S - Chiruchiru Left (ちるちる左よ) Orders Michiru to move left. Cannot be used while Michiru is readied.

Michiru enters her "ready" stance. In this stance, she cannot move but her assist specials are much faster and some get unique properties. When Michiru completes a readied attack, she will return to her normal stance. Cancelling into this move and its variants is crucial to Minagi's gameplan.
Michiru leaves the "ready" state and can move again.
Orders Michiru to move right. Cannot be used while Michiru is readied.
Orders Michiru to move left. Cannot be used while Michiru is readied.

variations.notes: 5S - Chiruchiru Setup (ちるちる構えて) Michiru enters her "ready" stance. In this stance, she cannot move but her assist specials are much faster and some get unique properties. When Michiru completes a readied attack, she will return to her normal stance. Cancelling into this move and its variants is crucial to Minagi's gameplan. 5S - Chiruchiru Stop Setup (ちるちる構え止め) Michiru leaves the "ready" state and can move again.
Orders Michiru to move left. Cannot be used while Michiru is readied.
Orders Michiru to move right. Cannot be used while Michiru is readied.

moves.moveName: Chiruchiru Kick  ちるちるキック
properties: Minagi tells Michiru to perform a kick. The properties and effects differ greatly between normal and readied states.
When Michiru is in normal state, this move has slow startup and high recovery as Michiru needs to walk up to the opponent.
When Michiru is in ready state, the startup becomes much faster, and the C version turns into a multi-hitting attack with huge frame advantage.
※Recovery values vary depending on Michiru's starting position relative to the opponent.

variations.notes: Michiru performs a basic single kick. Causes a wallbounce on hit which can be followed up with 236236C super. Gives exceptional frame advantage even on block.
Similar to A version but with longer active frames, making it easier to connect. Still causes wallbounce on hit and has great frame advantage.
Launches the opponent higher on hit, allowing for better combo extensions. Also has the best frame advantage on block, making it excellent for pressure.
When Michiru is in ready state, this version comes out much faster. Causes wallbounce on hit and has even better frame advantage on block.
Ready version with longer active frames. Similar properties to ready A but easier to connect with.
The most powerful variant. In ready state, this version hits multiple times (5 hits) and grants massive frame advantage. This is one of Minagi's primary pressure tools and combo extenders.

moves.moveName: Chiruchiru Drilling Bow Thigh  ちるちる穿弓腿
properties: Michiru performs an advancing leg attack. In normal state this move is very slow, but in ready state it comes out much faster.
The key property of this move is that Michiru can absorb one hit during her approach, functioning as a form of armor.
All versions are cancelable into FIC, allowing Minagi to extend combos or ensure safety.
In ready state, this becomes Michiru's primary anti-air option, though it has worse frame advantage.

variations.notes: Michiru performs a single hit leg attack. She can absorb one hit during her approach. Good frame advantage on block, and can be FIC canceled to ensure safety or extend combos.
Similar to A version but with longer active frames, making it easier to connect. The trade-off is slightly lower damage.
Multi-hit version that does three hits total. Has the most frame advantage on block, making it excellent for pressure. The hit absorption still only works for the first hit received.
When Michiru is ready, this version comes out much faster. The trade-off is that it's negative on block, so you must FIC cancel it for safety.
Ready version with longer active frames. Similar properties to ready A but easier to connect with. Still negative on block.
Multi-hit version in ready state. Unlike A and B versions, this is actually plus on block, making it a great pressure tool.

moves.moveName: Chiruchiru Iron Head Merit  ちるちる鉄頭功
properties: Michiru does a diving headbutt attack towards the opponent. This move's effectiveness was significantly reduced in balance patches.
In normal state, the attack has two phases: the initial dive followed by Michiru bouncing back up with another hit.
In ready state, this move comes out much faster and the C version has tracking properties.
The distance Michiru travels increases with button strength, with C version covering the most distance.

variations.notes: Michiru performs a diving headbutt with short range. After hitting the ground, she bounces back up which can hit a second time. Most useful as an approach tool rather than in neutral.
Medium range version of the headbutt attack. The bounce-back hit has slightly better range than the A version.
Longest range version of the headbutt. The bounce-back also travels further, which can be useful for catching opponents trying to punish the initial dive.
When Michiru is ready, this version comes out much faster. The short range remains the same as normal state, but the quick startup makes it more useful in combos.
Medium range version with fast startup. The bounce-back hit can sometimes catch opponents off guard due to its unusual timing.

The C version in ready state has the added property of tracking the opponent's position, making it more likely to connect. Has the longest range and can be used as a pseudo-anti-air in some situations.

moves.moveName: Chiruchiru Whirlwind Leg  ちるちる旋風脚
properties: Michiru jumps into the air and performs a spinning multi-hit kick. This move is primarily used as an aerial control tool.
The height of the jump, number of hits, and damage increases with button strength.
In ready state, the startup is significantly reduced, making it much more viable in combos and pressure.
This move can be used both on the ground and in the air, giving Minagi versatile control options.

variations.notes: Michiru jumps and performs a spinning kick with 4 hits. The normal state version has very slow startup, limiting its usefulness in neutral.
Michiru jumps higher and performs 6 hits, covering more vertical space. Useful for catching opponents trying to approach from above.
The C version has more hits (12), slightly faster startup, and jumps twice as high as the A version. Best for controlling vertical space but still too slow for direct pressure.
When Michiru is ready, this version comes out much faster. The shorter jump height makes it useful for quick air control in combos.
Ready version with medium jump height and 6 hits. The fast startup makes it viable as an anti-air option in some situations.
This version has the fastest startup of all variations (16 frames) and the highest jump. With 12 hits, it's excellent for aerial control and can be used to effectively zone out certain approaches.
All versions can also be performed in the air with similar properties. The air versions provide Minagi with good options for aerial pressure and controlling space.

moves.moveName: Rice Ticket Presentation  お米券進呈
properties: Minagi herself rushes forward with a ticket. Unlike Michiru-based specials, this move is performed by Minagi directly.
The C version is fully invincible from startup and is Minagi's primary reversal option.
All versions can be Full Inazuma Canceled (FIC) for combo extensions or safety.
Range increases with button strength, with C version traveling over a full screen distance.

variations.notes: Minagi rushes forward with a ticket, traveling about 75% of the screen distance. Fast startup but unsafe on block without FIC. Often used in combos due to its speed.
Travels about 90% of screen distance, allowing it to hit opponents who are almost fullscreen away. Slower startup and more unsafe on block compared to the A version.

The most important version - hits twice, travels over a full screen, and most importantly is fully invincible from frame 1. This is Minagi's primary reversal option and emergency escape tool. Still unsafe on block without FIC.

moves.moveName: Chiruchiru Kick Festival  ちるちるキック祭り
properties: Michiru performs a multi-hitting drill attack in the air, spinning rapidly towards the opponent.
Higher levels increase damage, hitbox size, and number of hits.
All versions provide massive frame advantage, making this super excellent for both combos and pressure.
The attack has no gaps between hits, so the opponent must block in the same direction throughout the entire super even if Michiru crosses up.

variations.notes: Level 1 super with 17 hits. Provides enormous frame advantage even on block, allowing Minagi to set up devastating mixups after. Can be used to end combos or as a pressure reset tool.
Level 2 super with 18 hits and increased damage per hit. Has slightly larger hitbox and duration than the A version, making it more likely to connect from farther ranges.

Level 3 super with 21 hits and significantly more damage. Has the largest hitbox and longest duration, making it excellent for punishing unsafe moves from almost any distance. The extreme frame advantage allows for easy mixups afterward.

moves.moveName: Chiruchiru Solar Plexus Break  ちるちる鳩尾ブレイク
properties: Michiru delivers a powerful single hit to the opponent's solar plexus.
Higher levels increase damage and hitstun/blockstun duration.
All versions are plus on block, but especially powerful on hit where they provide massive frame advantage for follow-ups.
In ready state, this move becomes even faster and has even more frame advantage.

variations.notes: Level 1 super with fast startup. Provides huge advantage on hit and is still very plus on block. Good for both combo endings and pressure resets.
Level 2 super with increased damage and even more hitstun. The frame advantage on hit is so large that Minagi can perform almost any follow-up she wants.
Level 3 super with maximum damage and hitstun. The extreme frame advantage on hit allows for combos that would otherwise be impossible.
When Michiru is ready, this version comes out even faster and has more frame advantage on hit. Excellent for combo extensions.
Ready version of the level 2 super. The frame advantage is so massive that Minagi can do almost anything afterward, including setting up complex Michiru-based mixups.
Ready version of the level 3 super. The nearly +90 frame advantage on hit allows for some of the most damaging follow-ups in the game.
All versions can also be performed in the air with similar properties but different frame data. Air versions are especially useful for extending air combos.

properties: Either Minagi or Michiru blow soap bubbles that travel forward. The bubbles expand over time, increasing their hitbox.
Higher button strengths increase the number of bubbles and decrease the gap between them.
This super can be performed by either Minagi or Michiru, with different properties for each.
When Michiru performs it, the super creates more bubbles and has longer duration, making it better for zoning.

variations.notes: Minagi blows 5 bubbles with a 9 frame gap between them. The bubbles expand over time, making them useful for zoning even if initially dodged.
Minagi blows 11 bubbles with a 6 frame gap between them. The increased number of bubbles makes this version better for zoning and combo extensions.
Minagi blows 24 bubbles with a 3 frame gap between them. The tiny gap makes this version nearly impossible to dodge through, creating an effective wall of hitboxes.
When Michiru performs this super, she creates 10-11 bubbles with similar gaps to Minagi's version, but covering more horizontal space. Startup varies depending on Michiru's position.
Michiru creates 15-16 bubbles with increased horizontal coverage. Excellent for controlling space and forcing the opponent to block or take risks.
Michiru creates 18-19 bubbles with the maximum horizontal coverage and minimal gaps. Creates a nearly impenetrable wall for several seconds, giving Minagi time to set up mixups or heal.

properties: Minagi's Final Memory attack. Minagi and Michiru call stars to fall from the sky, creating a sustained barrage of projectiles.
The attack lasts for an extended period, covering a large area of the screen.
Hitting Michiru will cancel the FM and stop it from producing more stars, but hitting Minagi does not stop the FM.
Each star does 300 damage, knocks down on hit, and can be used to control space or extend combos.

variations.notes: Minagi and Michiru call stars to fall from the sky. Lasts for quite a while, creating a constant hazard for the opponent. Hitting Michiru will cancel the FM and stop it from producing more stars. Hitting Minagi does not stop the FM. Each star knocks down on hit.
